WantedBy=timers.target

> @tahmed-dev not able to completely follow PR description .
> Eg: snmp.timer has Install section but still we do do not want to enable snmp.service ?
> [Install]
> WantedBy=timers.target

@abdosi, This is correct, we do not want to enable snmp/telemetry .service. The issue was reported by systemd as follows:
```
Aug 25 18:47:59.248264 str-s6000-acs-14 INFO hostcfgd[22667]: The unit files have no installation config (WantedBy=, RequiredBy=, Also=,
Aug 25 18:47:59.250047 str-s6000-acs-14 INFO hostcfgd[22667]: Alias= settings in the [Install] section, and DefaultInstance= for template
Aug 25 18:47:59.251773 str-s6000-acs-14 INFO hostcfgd[22667]: units). This means they are not meant to be enabled using systemctl.
Aug 25 18:47:59.254822 str-s6000-acs-14 INFO hostcfgd[22667]:  
Aug 25 18:47:59.256584 str-s6000-acs-14 INFO hostcfgd[22667]: Possible reasons for having this kind of units are:
Aug 25 18:47:59.262071 str-s6000-acs-14 INFO hostcfgd[22667]: • A unit may be statically enabled by being symlinked from another unit's
Aug 25 18:47:59.263599 str-s6000-acs-14 INFO hostcfgd[22667]:   .wants/ or .requires/ directory.
Aug 25 18:47:59.265389 str-s6000-acs-14 INFO hostcfgd[22667]: • A unit's purpose may be to act as a helper for some other unit which has
Aug 25 18:47:59.268989 str-s6000-acs-14 INFO hostcfgd[22667]:   a requirement dependency on it.
Aug 25 18:47:59.270647 str-s6000-acs-14 INFO hostcfgd[22667]: • A unit may be started when needed via activation (socket, path, timer,
Aug 25 18:47:59.272414 str-s6000-acs-14 INFO hostcfgd[22667]:   D-Bus, udev, scripted systemctl call, ...).
Aug 25 18:47:59.274089 str-s6000-acs-14 INFO hostcfgd[22667]: • In case of template units, the unit is meant to be enabled with some
Aug 25 18:47:59.275855 str-s6000-acs-14 INFO hostcfgd[22667]:   instance name specified.
Aug 25 18:47:59.279172 str-s6000-acs-14 INFO hostcfgd: Running cmd: 'sudo systemctl start snmp.service'
```

comments.body: @SuvarnaMeenakshi: This submodule update cannot be cherry-picked to 201911. I removed the checkmark and did not add the label. There is a separate 201911 branch of sonic-snmpagent; the relevant PRs in the sonic-snmpagent repo need to be cherry-picked into the 201911 branch in that repo, then @abdosi will update the submodule in the 201911 branch of sonic-buildimage.
@SuvarnaMeenakshi , @abdosi , are we ready to advance snmpagent submodule in 201911 now?  Thanks.

Just wanted to add a note that we should probably now also check the `has_timer` field when restarting services in the `config` command: https://github.com/Azure/sonic-utilities/blob/master/config/main.py#L238

> Just wanted to add a note that we should probably now also check the `has_timer` field when restarting services in the `config` command: https://github.com/Azure/sonic-utilities/blob/master/config/main.py#L238

Good point! I was thinking about it last night, however the rationale is to delay non critical service during boot time in order to meet fast/warm boot time requirements. During config load/reload, we don't have such urgency. What do you think?

> Good point! I was thinking about it last night, however the rationale is to delay non critical service during boot time in order to meet fast/warm boot time requirements. During config load/reload, we don't have such urgency. What do you think?

If that is the only rationale, and there is no other reason for the delay (race conditions, etc.), then I agree we don't need to be concerned about config load/reload.

> > Good point! I was thinking about it last night, however the rationale is to delay non critical service during boot time in order to meet fast/warm boot time requirements. During config load/reload, we don't have such urgency. What do you think?
> 
> If that is the only rationale, and there is no other reason for the delay (race conditions, etc.), then I agree we don't need to be concerned about config load/reload.

@tahmed-dev Adding to @jleveque point currently on doing config reload seeing this. May be we need to check if we want to add .timer in config commands also

sudo config reload -y
Executing stop of service telemetry...
Warning: Stopping telemetry.service, but it can still be activated by:
telemetry.timer

comments.body:
Can you test the case, where node is really not ready and see what happens, when the node become ready.

You may disable/enable kubelet service on node, to simulate this.

What is the minimum required to get the node, marked as ready ?

> Can you test the case, where node is really not ready and see what happens, when the node become ready.
> You may disable/enable kubelet service on node, to simulate this.

When we don't have a CNI, you can see the reason for the NotReady label with `kubectl describe node <NotReadyNodeName>`
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/67024108/89480151-3be34500-d75a-11ea-9180-6c6de6162607.png)
We see that the reason is that "cni config is uninitialized"
After stopping kubelet, we see updated reason for NotReady: Kubelet stopped posting node status: 
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/67024108/89480310-a1373600-d75a-11ea-849b-1e841d08ef52.png)
After restarting kubelet, we see the original reason for NotReady: "cni config is uninitialized"
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/67024108/89480414-de9bc380-d75a-11ea-91e0-9e2b81994ab6.png)

> What is the minimum required to get the node, marked as ready ?

So it seems, the minimum requirement to get the node marked as Ready is to deploy a CNI. KubeNet should not take much extra space, though it adds functionality that we should not have any use for beyond getting the status to show Ready.
Thanks Isabel. Can you please add a sample manifest with that toleration,  in this PR as comments ?

> What is the minimum requirement to get the node marked as ready?

I found a way to get around the CNI check. We can manually create the CNI config file. Essentially, the kubelet is searching for a config file in `/etc/cni/net.d` directory. Deploying flannel as a CNI normally places a flannel config file in that directory. When the kubelet doesn't find the config file, the check fails and node's status shows as NotReady. 

I manually created a flannel config file in that directory (without setting up flannel), and the node's status changes to Ready. Once I remove the file config file and restart the kubelet, the node's status updates to NotReady. I tested this because I noticed that the node status showed Ready as long as I deployed flannel once, and stayed Ready even after I deleted flannel (deleting flannel does not delete the config file) when I used the same SONiC image. If we manually create this file, we don't have to add any unnecessary networking complexity by deploying an unused CNI, and we can better tell when nodes are truly NotReady in our use case. Renuka suggests we may add this in kube_join script.


> Can you please add a sample manifest with that toleration, in this PR as comments ?

We should not need tolerations any more if we manually add a config file (confirmed with local testing), but here is the format of my original toleration, parallel to `volumes` and `containers` in the manifest definition: 

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/67024108/89567833-f2d9d200-d7e7-11ea-8420-60d200b3b018.png)
dependency  https://github.com/Azure/sonic-platform-common/pull/108 merged, this one ready to merge

comments.body: Ok Sure Joe, that is good as there are a few overlapping functions !

Are these changes intended to be backported to 201911? Also please feel free to review https://github.com/Azure/sonic-buildimage/pull/5003, now that you've been working on some of the packages which will be affected by that PR.

> Are these changes intended to be backported to 201911? Also please feel free to review #5003, now that you've been working on some of the packages which will be affected by that PR.

Yes these changes are needed for 201911 as well.

> Yes these changes are needed for 201911 as well.

Then I think we should also backport https://github.com/Azure/sonic-buildimage/pull/5003 and all related changes to 201911 in order to keep the code as similar as possible for the ease of backporting any future bugfixes/enhancements. Do you agree?

> > Yes these changes are needed for 201911 as well.
> 
> Then I think we should also backport #5003 and all related changes to 201911 in order to keep the code as similar as possible for the ease of backporting any future bugfixes/enhancements. Do you agree?

Yes Joe, good to backport to 201911 so that both branch are similar.
Btw .. once we move the daemon_base.py into the sonic-py-common, the only file remaining in sonic_daemon_base is task_base.py. We could remove this package sonic_daemon_base ?  **Ok I see this in you followup action items !**
The only changes for this PR that is significant is in this file src/sonic-py-common/sonic_py_common/daemon_base.py

comments.body: @renukamanavalan , @msreddypaluru , @dev-aviz please review and check if there are any more issues to be resolved.

> Changes looks good. I hit a build issue when I try to build sonic-host-service on top of sonic-build image. If you don't find any build issues you can merge the changes.
> 
> SONiC Build System
> 
> Build Configuration
> "CONFIGURED_PLATFORM" : "broadcom"
> "CONFIGURED_ARCH" : "amd64"
> "SONIC_CONFIG_PRINT_DEPENDENCIES" : ""
> "SONIC_BUILD_JOBS" : "1"
> "SONIC_CONFIG_MAKE_JOBS" : "8"
> "SONIC_USE_DOCKER_BUILDKIT" : ""
> "USERNAME" : "admin"
> "PASSWORD" : "YourPaSsWoRd"
> "ENABLE_DHCP_GRAPH_SERVICE" : ""
> "SHUTDOWN_BGP_ON_START" : ""
> "INSTALL_KUBERNETES" : "n"
> "ENABLE_PFCWD_ON_START" : ""
> "INSTALL_DEBUG_TOOLS" : ""
> "ROUTING_STACK" : "frr"
> "FRR_USER_UID" : "300"
> "FRR_USER_GID" : "300"
> "ENABLE_SYNCD_RPC" : ""
> "ENABLE_ORGANIZATION_EXTENSIONS" : "y"
> "HTTP_PROXY" : ""
> "HTTPS_PROXY" : ""
> "ENABLE_SYSTEM_TELEMETRY" : "y"
> "ENABLE_RESTAPI" : "n"
> "ENABLE_ZTP" : ""
> **"ENABLE_HOST_SERVICE" : "y"**
> "SONIC_DEBUGGING_ON" : ""
> "SONIC_PROFILING_ON" : ""
> "KERNEL_PROCURE_METHOD" : "build"
> "BUILD_TIMESTAMP" : "20200727.220727"
> "BUILD_LOG_TIMESTAMP" : "none"
> "BLDENV" : "buster"
> "VS_PREPARE_MEM" : "yes"
> "ENABLE_SFLOW" : "y"
> "ENABLE_NAT" : "y"
> "TELEMETRY_WRITABLE" : ""
> 
> "SONIC_DPKG_CACHE_METHOD" : "none"
> 
> **[ FAIL LOG START ] [ target/debs/buster/sonic-host-service_1.0.0_all.deb ] [ REASON ] : target/debs/buster/sonic-host-service_1.0.0_all.deb does not exist [ FLAGS FILE ] : [] [ FLAGS DEPENDS ] : [] [ FLAGS DIFF ] : [] [ DEP DEPENDS ] : [] [ SMDEP DEPENDS ] : [] [ TARGET DEPENDS ] : [.platform] make[1]: Entering directory '/sonic/src/sonic-host-service' make[1]: *** No rule to make target '/sonic/target/debs/buster/sonic-host-service_1.0.0_all.deb'. Stop. make[1]: Leaving directory '/sonic/src/sonic-host-service' [ FAIL LOG END ] [ target/debs/buster/sonic-host-service_1.0.0_all.deb ] make: *** [slave.mk:377: target/debs/buster/sonic-host-service_1.0.0_all.deb] Error 1**
> Makefile.work:224: recipe for target 'all' failed
> make[1]: *** [all] Error 2
> make[1]: Leaving directory '/home/aviz/mp/sonic-buildimage'
> Makefile:7: recipe for target 'all' failed
> make: *** [all] Error 2

I'm not able to reproduce the build failure. I see that error only when `ENABLE_HOST_SERVICE = n`, and only if I try to directly make that package.

Hi @msreddypaluru ,
Can you please confirm, if it builds fine, per Nirenjan's comments ? Please reply ASAP.

Thank you,
Renuka

I've updated the code to resolve the conflicts and use the new `INCLUDE_` form of the configuration options.

@msreddypaluru, @dev-aviz, @renukamanavalan, please review ASAP.

According to the SAI spec, the buffer pool size includes the reserved buffer for all pg/queues. So that would mean we would have the same pool size specified for T1 and T0 templates and internally subtract the reserved space to get the actual shared pool size to allocate.
This is followed by other ASICs which do not include a headroom pool
https://github.com/opencomputeproject/SAI/blob/master/doc/QOS/SAI-Proposal-buffers-Ver4.docx

> ingress_lossy_profile
Hi,
`ingress_lossy_profile` is referenced in `BUFFER_PG|<port>|0`. Please check [sonic-buildimage/build_templates/buffers_config.j2](https://github.com/Azure/sonic-buildimage/blob/master/files/build_templates/buffers_config.j2#L136)
Do you have buffer templates for 2700 C32 sku?

> Why different SKUs get different Xoff sizes under the same link speed and cable length?

If they are based on different ASICs, they can have different xoff sizes because of different cell sizes.
If you're not meaning this, can you elaborate it a bit more?

> Do you have buffer templates for 2700 C32 sku?

Yes. All the buffer templates of SKUs based 2700 share the same templates.
We can provide the specific template for C32 if you provide the cable lengths of ports for t0/t1.
Are they:
- t0: 28 * server ports (5m) + 4 leaf ports (40m)
- t1: 24 * TOR ports (40m) + 8 spine ports (300m)

?

> > Why different SKUs get different Xoff sizes under the same link speed and cable length?
> 
> If they are based on different ASICs, they can have different xoff sizes because of different cell sizes.
> If you're not meaning this, can you elaborate it a bit more?

Got it! What are the cell sizes of 3800 and 4600?

> > Do you have buffer templates for 2700 C32 sku?
> 
> Yes. All the buffer templates of SKUs based 2700 share the same templates.
> We can provide the specific template for C32 if you provide the cable lengths of ports for t0/t1.
> Are they:
> 
> * t0: 28 * server ports (5m) + 4 leaf ports (40m)
> * t1: 24 * TOR ports (40m) + 8 spine ports (300m)
> 
> ?
Let's assume the worst case.
t0: 16 * server ports (100g, 5M) + 16 leaf ports (100g, 40m)
t1:  16 * TOR ports (100g, 40m) + 16 spine ports (100g, 300m)

> > Let's assume the worst case.
> > t0: 16 * server ports (100g, 5M) + 16 leaf ports (100g, 40m)
> > t1:  16 * TOR ports (100g, 40m) + 16 spine ports (100g, 300m)

Hi @liat-grozovik @lguohan ,
If we all agree on this setup I will calculate the buffer pool size for `Mellanox-SN2700` based on this.

> D48C8 and C32 should use different T1 templates

Done. Please review. @baiwei0427 @neethajohn
@baiwei0427 are we good to go with these values?

> @baiwei0427 are we good to go with these values?

I will do calculations tomorrow and get back to you as soon as possible,

@baiwei0427 could you also provide the cable length information for calculating pool size for 3800 as well?
For 3800, we have the following SKUs:
- Mellanox-SN3800-C64
- Mellanox-SN3800-D112C8
- Mellanox-SN3800-D24C52
- Mellanox-SN3800-D28C50

thank you!

> @baiwei0427 could you also provide the cable length information for calculating pool size for 3800 as well?
> For 3800, we have the following SKUs:
> 
> * Mellanox-SN3800-C64
> * Mellanox-SN3800-D112C8
> * Mellanox-SN3800-D24C52
> * Mellanox-SN3800-D28C50
> 
> thank you!

Server to T0: 5M
T0 to T1: 40M
T1 to T2: 300M

@baiwei0427 
> Server to T0: 5M
> T0 to T1: 40M
> T1 to T2: 300M

How many ports are connected to servers, TORs, leaf/spine routers respectively in each of the SKU?
Thanks
@liat-grozovik  @stephenxs  I did calculations for D48C8 T0, SN2700 T0, and SN2700 T1 and got similar results.
Note: Leaving aside new requirements for SN3800. this PR is for updating SN2700 SKUs.
